verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron, saying to them:
verses.comment: God addresses Moses and Aaron as mediators for His people, setting a precedent for divinely appointed leaders who serve as a bridge between God and His people.

verses.text: "Speak to the Israelites, saying: These are the creatures that you may eat among all the animals that are on the earth:
verses.comment: God gives clear dietary laws which set Israel apart from other nations. These rules symbolize holiness and separation, themes fulfilled spiritually in Christ. The echoes of these dietary distinctions can be seen referenced by Peter's vision in Acts 10:9-16, which demonstrates an evolving understanding of purity.

verses.text: Whatever has a split hoof, completely divided, and chews the cud among the animals, you may eat.
verses.comment: The distinction demands both conditions: a divided hoof and chewing cud—symbolizing the need for true inward and outward purity. This anticipates Christ’s emphasis on clean hearts rather than external observances (Matt. 15:17-20).

verses.text: Nevertheless, you shall not eat of those that chew the cud or have a split hoof: the camel, because it chews the cud but does not have a divided hoof; it is unclean to you.
verses.comment: The failure to fulfil both conditions renders the camel unclean. These particularities highlight the precision and intention behind God’s law, foreshadowing the need for fullness of truth embodied in Christ.

verses.text: The rock hyrax, because it chews the cud but does not have a divided hoof, it is unclean to you.
verses.comment: Each animal singled out is for the purpose of teaching the importance of detail in spiritual discipline.

verses.text: The rabbit, because it chews the cud but does not have a divided hoof, it is unclean to you.
verses.comment: Note the repetition: incomplete conformity excludes one from spiritual 'cleanliness'.

verses.text: The pig, because it has a split hoof completely divided but does not chew the cud, it is unclean to you.
verses.comment: The pig meets only the external requirement, not the internal. The lesson is to seek both outer and inner transformation, also seen in Christ’s rebuke of legalism.

verses.text: You shall not eat their flesh or touch their carcasses. They are unclean to you.
verses.comment: Touching even the remains brings ritual impurity, illustrating the pervasive effect of sin and the need for true cleansing—a theme seen again in the New Testament with Christ’s cleansing power.

verses.text: "Of all that are in the waters, these may you eat: whatever has fins and scales in the waters, in the seas and in the rivers, those you may eat.
verses.comment: Symbolically, fins and scales represent readiness and armor against impurities, subtly referencing Christian virtues and the spiritual armor of faith (Eph. 6:11-17).

verses.text: But whatever does not have fins and scales among all that are in the seas and rivers, of all that move in the waters and of any living thing which is in the waters, they are detestable to you.
verses.comment: Most aquatic creatures are excluded, reflecting the importance of boundaries for spiritual living.

verses.text: They shall be detestable to you. You shall not eat of their flesh, and you shall detest their carcasses.
verses.comment: Detestation implies not just avoidance but active rejection, underscoring seriousness about spiritual purity.

verses.text: Whatever has no fins or scales in the waters is detestable to you.
verses.comment: Absolute consistency in God's commands, inviting trust in the completeness of divine revelation.

verses.text: "Among the birds, these you shall detest; they shall not be eaten; they are detestable: the eagle, the vulture, the black vulture,
verses.comment: Birds of prey are excluded, often associated in Scripture with judgment, reinforcing God’s call to avoid what is spiritually dangerous.

verses.text: the kite and the falcon after its kind,
verses.comment: Listing of species educates Israel to discern spiritually between what is licit and illicit, similar to spiritual discernment taught in the New Testament.

verses.text: every raven after its kind,
verses.comment: Ravens, though used by God to feed Elijah (1 Kings 17:6), remain unclean, reminding us of the distinction between God’s providence and ritual purity.

verses.text: the ostrich, the owl, the seagull, and the hawk after its kind,
verses.comment: Notable as creatures of darkness or isolation—symbolizing spiritual exile or ignorance, themes fulfilled as Christ brings true light and communion.

verses.text: the little owl, the cormorant, and the great owl,
verses.comment: A continuing list showing the clarity of God’s revelation and His concern for the details of His people’s lives.

verses.text: the white owl, the desert owl, and the osprey,
verses.comment: Emphasis remains on purity and separation—distinctive marks of God’s holy people.

verses.text: the stork, the heron after its kind, the hoopoe, and the bat.
verses.comment: Suggests the exclusion of things associated with unclean habits or nocturnality—looking toward themes of spiritual daylight in Christ (John 8:12).

verses.text: "All flying insects that walk on all fours are detestable to you.
verses.comment: Insects generally are considered unclean, except for certain exceptions below, emphasizing discernment even in small matters.

verses.text: Yet among all the flying insects that walk on all fours you may eat those which have jointed legs above their feet, to leap on the earth.
verses.comment: Locusts and similar insects are permitted—an unusual exception, later referenced in the diet of John the Baptist (Matt. 3:4). Openness to divine exceptions.

verses.text: Of these you may eat: the locust after its kind, the cricket after its kind, the grasshopper after its kind.
verses.comment: Echoes to John's austere preparations for Christ’s ministry—foreshadowing the need for spiritual readiness for the coming Kingdom.

verses.text: But all other flying insects which have four feet shall be detestable to you.
verses.comment: Outside divinely revealed exceptions, all others are forbidden—showing importance of strict fidelity to God's word and established authority.

verses.text: "By these you shall become unclean: whoever touches their carcass shall be unclean until evening.
verses.comment: Touching the carcass brings temporary impurity, reflecting spiritual consequences for contact with sin and the necessity for purification—a theme typified in sacramental theology.

verses.text: And whoever carries any part of their carcass shall wash his clothes and be unclean until evening.
verses.comment: Washing symbolizes both ritual and spiritual cleansing—anticipating the cleansing waters of Baptism (John 3:5).

verses.text: "Every animal which has a split hoof, but is not completely divided, or does not chew the cud, is unclean to you; whoever touches them shall be unclean.
verses.comment: Incomplete adherence to God’s pattern consistently imparts uncleanness—mirroring necessity for fullness of truth and unity.

verses.text: Whatever goes on its paws, among all animals that go on all fours, are unclean to you; whoever touches their carcass shall be unclean until evening.
verses.comment: Paw-walking creatures, often predators, are unclean—again tying cleanliness to docile, approachable habits, resonant with Christ as the gentle shepherd.

verses.text: Whoever carries any part of their carcass shall wash his clothes and be unclean until evening; they are unclean to you.
verses.comment: Again, repetition of the washing ritual highlights God’s intent for continual renewal and purification—not merely guilt but the ongoing spiritual journey.

verses.text: "These are unclean to you among the crawling creatures that crawl on the earth: the mole, the mouse, and the great lizard of its kind,
verses.comment: Small, hidden animals represent things lurking beneath the surface—pointing to Christ’s call for purity at every level, seen in His rebuke of secret sin.

verses.text: the gecko, the monitor lizard, the lizard, the sand lizard, and the chameleon.
verses.comment: Each named to leave no ambiguity—showing God's order extends to the smallest details in creation; such detailed care echoes the structure of spiritual governance.

verses.text: These are unclean to you among all that crawl; whoever touches them when they are dead shall be unclean until evening.
verses.comment: Scripture’s repetition strengthens the lesson: contact with impurity—even accidental—necessitates careful restoration.

verses.text: "Anything on which one of them falls when they are dead shall be unclean: whether it is a wooden vessel, or clothing, or skin, or sack, any vessel by which work is done, it must be put into water and will be unclean until evening; then it will be clean.
verses.comment: Contact with impurity affects even everyday objects, showing how pervasive holiness is in life. The ritual cleaning prefigures sacramental absolution’s transformative power.

verses.text: Any earthen vessel into which any of them falls, whatever is in it shall be unclean, and you shall break it.
verses.comment: Earthen vessels must be broken—symbolizing the fragility of our humanity, and the necessary destruction of what is deeply contaminated. See Paul’s imagery of earthen vessels (2 Cor. 4:7).

verses.text: Any food that may be eaten, on which such water comes, shall be unclean. Any drink that may be drunk in every such vessel shall be unclean.
verses.comment: Purity law extends to food and drink—anticipating the later concerns with Eucharistic purity and reverence for holy things.

verses.text: Everything on which their carcass falls shall be unclean; oven and stove shall be broken down, for they are unclean, and shall be unclean to you.
verses.comment: Ovens/stoves represent sources of daily sustenance—here requiring complete renewal after defilement, a spiritual parallel to renewal after sin.

verses.text: Nevertheless, a spring or a cistern holding water shall be clean, but whatever touches their carcass shall be unclean.
verses.comment: Natural springs remain clean—a hint at living water as a symbol of grace and spiritual life (John 4:10-14).

verses.text: If any part of their carcass falls on any seed used for sowing, it is clean.
verses.comment: Seeds for sowing remain clean—a spiritual parallel to the Word planted in the hearts, unable to be corrupted before it is received (1 Pet. 1:23).

verses.text: But if water has been put on the seed and any part of their carcass falls on it, it is unclean to you.
verses.comment: Once 'water' activates the seed, it becomes vulnerable—offering deep reflection on baptismal preparation and preventing corruption in the journey to spiritual rebirth.

verses.text: "If any animal which you may eat dies, whoever touches its carcass shall be unclean until evening.
verses.comment: Even clean animals in death can impart impurity—reminder of mortality and the importance of ritual restoration, pointing ultimately towards resurrection in Christ.

verses.text: Whoever eats of its carcass shall wash his clothes and be unclean until evening. Whoever carries its carcass shall wash his clothes and be unclean until evening.
verses.comment: Those eating or handling the carcass must be cleansed—showing the need for constant spiritual vigilance and the cycle of penance and reconciliation.

verses.text: "Every creeping thing that creeps on the earth is detestable; it shall not be eaten.
verses.comment: Creeping things symbolize uncleanness, suggesting to believers the need for separation from spiritual corruption.

verses.text: Whatever goes on its belly, or goes on all fours, or has many feet among all creeping things that creep on the earth, you shall not eat, for they are detestable.
verses.comment: Repetition of uncleanness for crawling creatures—underscoring God’s persistent call to holiness.

verses.text: Do not make yourselves detestable by any creeping thing that creeps, and do not make yourselves unclean with them, lest you become unclean.
verses.comment: Core teaching: avoidance of what makes unclean. This repeats throughout Scripture and finds fulfillment in Christ’s complete cleansing of sin.

verses.text: For I am the LORD your God. Consecrate yourselves therefore, and be holy, for I am holy. You shall not defile yourselves with any crawling thing that moves on the earth.
verses.comment: This verse is pivotal and later quoted in the New Testament, tying the law to the call to spiritual transformation: holiness not as mere ritual, but as the pattern of God Himself.

verses.text: For I am the LORD, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt, to be your God. Therefore you shall be holy, for I am holy.
verses.comment: God roots His call to holiness in His redeeming act, showing how redemption and relationship always demand response—later fulfilled perfectly in Christ who liberates and sanctifies.

verses.text: This is the law regarding animals, birds, all living creatures that move in the waters, and all living things that crawl on the earth;
verses.comment: Broad scope: God’s law covers every part of life. This prefigures a comprehensive spiritual code, ultimately fulfilled and explained in the ministry of Christ and His apostles.

verses.text: to distinguish between the unclean and the clean, and between the living creatures that may be eaten and those that may not be eaten.
verses.comment: God’s gift of discernment is at the heart of the law—preparation for receiving the fullness of truth and the ability to live wholly as God’s people. Christ fulfills this with a new law written on our hearts (Heb. 8:10).
